title: Ethnicity, Networks and Voice Mechanisms in Established and Hard to Reach BME Communities: Capacity Building and Beyond
abstractText:
Since the completion of the seminar series, ‘Networks and Voice Mechanisms in Established and Hard-to-Reach BME Communities: Capacity Building and Beyond’, a number of research outcomes have been successfully progressed and reported in the Impact Report and Impact Record submitted March 2011.

These outcomes have now been progressed further and form the basis of this 2012 Impact update. These include: the publication of two journal special editions (rated at 3* quality according to the Association of Business Schools journal quality guide); the setting up of a research network, the Voice and Ethnicity Research and Action Network, VERN, that builds on the findings and networks from the seminar series,  and the launch of a dedicated website. Additionally, a VERN launch event has been completed (roundtable discussion format) with both researchers and practitioners in attendance.

VERN also has established institutional links with a number of research centres including CERIC (University of Leeds), The Fairness of Work Research Group (University of Manchester), Migrant Workers and Action Research Group, Strathclyde University and PRIMAL (University of Paris, Nanterre).  Finally, VERN members submitted an application to the Joseph Rowntree Foundation (on ethnicity and poverty) and though unsuccessful, the application was shortlisted.
